lines.text: Tell me, Mr. Williams, were you unhappy as a child?
Not really. I had a perfectly normal childhood.
I see. You wanted to kill your father and sleep with you mother.

[to Sheriff Hartman]
If he's gonna talk dirty ...
When you were in grammar school, did you practice self-abuse?
No, sir. I don't believe in it. I would never abuse myself or anybody else. I love people. I love all people.
I suppose that cop committed suicide!
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: Let us get back to masturbation. Did your father ever catch you in the act?
Oh, my father was - was never home. He was a conductor on the Chicago-Northwestern.

Very significant. Your father wore a uniform, just like that policeman. And when he pulled out that gun, an obvious phallic symbol, you thought he was your father, and he was going to use it to hurt your mother.

[to Sheriff Hartman]
He's crazy.
[last lines]
That train that just left, what's the first stop?
Gary, Indiana.
All right. Send a message to the police chief at Gary, Indiana. Tell him to meet the midnight train to Philadelphia and arrest one Hildy Johnson.
Hildy Johnson?
Yeah. Son of a bitch stole my watch.

[after unsuccessfully posing as probation officer Otto Fishbein]
Tell Hildy I wish him all the luck in the world, and I mean it, or my name isn't Otto Fishbein.
Get yer head back in there, you God Damned turtle!
May the wind at your back never be your own.

[picks up his phone]
This is Bensinger. Give me a rewrite man. Oh, Marty, is that you?
[reads from notes]
"New lead on the Earl Williams Hanging"... Yes, the execution is still set for seven o'clock in the morning. "The authorities are prepared for a general uprising of radicals at that time".

[picks up his phone while playing poker]
Murphy here. Get me rewrite.
"Extra guards have just been thrown around the jail, the municipal building, railroad terminals, elevated stations".
Sheriff Hartman's just put 200 more relatives on the payroll to protect the city against the Red Army, which is leaving Moscow in a couple of minutes. Bet a dime.
shrimp cocktail with Thousand Island dressing, rare roast beef, Brussels sprouts, apple pie à la mode, Ovaltine".
For his last meal, Williams is getting a 95-cent Blue Plate Special from the greasy spoon across the street.

"At nine o'clock tonight, Williams will be examined by still another psycholigist, Dr. Max J. Eggelhofer, at the request of The Friends of American Liberty"... Eggelhofer. Yes, he's from Vienna... It's in my story this morning! He wrote that book, "Self-Abuse and Anti-Social Behavior".
Poor bastard's gonna swing in the morning, and this big brain from Vienna wants to ask him if he played with himself when he was five. More later.
[hangs up]
Goodbye, Duffy. Watch the diabetes. Walter, it's been fun.
What's he mean by that?
He's leaving us. Getting married.
Yeah? That hostess at the Hotsy-Totsy Club?
You're not even close. Why, this is a very classy dame. Philadephia. Studied to be a concert pianist.
Where in the hell would you meet a concert pianist?
Well, actually, she's a widow. Husband cracked up in a brand-new Packard. Only had 18 miles on it. So, to support herself, she's playing the organ at the Balaban & Katz Theater.
The one in the Loop?
Yeah. We've been dating three months.
Jeez, Hildy. why didn't you tell me? Kid, I woulda thrown you a little farewell party...
Oh, no, no, no! I know your farewell parties! When Ben Hecht was leaving for Hollywood, you slipped a micky in his gin fizz. It took four of us to get on the California Limited.
You don't mind waiting, do you?
What's there to mind? The night is young, the orchids are smelling, the meter is running.
[click]
Just made another nickel.
You don't have to answer this, Mollie, but is it true what they said in the papers?
Is what true?
That you were going to marry me on the gallows.
Well, if it's in the papers, it must be true. They wouldn't print a lie.
I never said that I loved Earl Williams and was willing to marry him on the gallows. You made that up!
Oh, come on. You've been sucking around that cuckoo ever since he's been in the death house.
Everybody knows you're his soul-mate.

That's a lot of bunk! Like all that other stuff you been writing. Calling me an Angel of the Pavement and the Midnight Madonna. Who ya kiddin'? I'm a two-dollar whore from Division Street and you know it!

[walks into the press room to see the reporters drinking liquor]
Ah, what's the idea, fellas? You know better than that. This is a government building!
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: Uh, hi, sheriff.
What'll ya have?
I got a good mind to have you all locked up!
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: The state's attorney wouldn't like it, because I bought that stuff from his brother.

[the sheriff is passing out tickets to the execution]
Daily News. Examiner.
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: Here you are, Rudy. The new man.
Oh, what happened? They finally fire you?
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: I'm retiring to my country estate outside Philadelphia.
Well, in that case, I will have a drink!
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: No, you won't. Not my liquor!
What should I do with the second ticket?
lines.character: Rudy Keppler of the Chicago Examiner

lines.text: Sell it to a scalper, like the sheriff does.
Sorry to break in, Sheriff, but we've located Williams. This time, for real.
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: Where?
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: On North Wabash, at the offices of the Friends of American Liberty. One of our patrols spotted him in the alley.
All right. Get every available man. Seal off the whole area. But remember, God damn it, I want him taken alive!
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: Check.
Pete, get the Governor on the phone.
Oh, you can't.
What do you mean, we can't?
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: He's gone fishing. Just him, and an Indian guide, and a canoe. No phone, no nothin'.
He sure picked a hell of a time to go fishing.

[phone rings]
Excuse me.
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: [exits]
Uh, just between us, it's not really fishing, because that Indian guide is really a girl. She' isn't even Indian. She's from New Jersey.

[holding up his phone]
He's waiting for instructions. What are we gonna do?
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: Tell him to shoot to kill.
What?
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: Shoot to kill, I said.
I - I don't know, Herbie. What about that reprieve? I-if it ever comes out ...
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text: Nobody reprieved that policeman he shot. There was no clemency, either. Do what I tell you!

[on phone]
Jacobi, you there? Listen. Shoot to kill! You heard me!
lines.character: 'Honest Pete' Hartman Sheriff of Clark County

lines.text:
[after being wounded by Earl Williams]
Fruitcake, Fruitcake!
